courses.title: Support for Precalculus
courses.description: Practicum for Learning Support students enrolled in MATH 1113 (Precalculus).

courses.title: Support for College Algebra
courses.description: This Learning Support course provides corequisite support in mathematics for students enrolled in MATH 1111 – College Algebra. Topics will parallel topics being studied in MATH 1111 and the course will provide support for the essential quantitative skills needed to be successful in MATH 1111. Taken with MATH 1111, this course provides an in-depth study of the properties of algebraic, exponential and logarithmic functions as needed for calculus. Emphasis is on using algebraic and graphical techniques for solving problems involving linear, quadratic, piece-wise defined, rational, polynomial, exponential and logarithmic functions.

courses.title: College Algebra
courses.description: This course provides an in-depth study of the properties of algebraic, exponential and logarithmic functions as needed for calculus. Emphasis is on using algebraic and graphical techniques for solving problems involving linear, quadratic, piece-wise defined, rational, polynomial, exponential and logarithmic functions.

courses.title: Pre-calculus
courses.description: This course is an intensive study of the basic functions needed for the study of calculus. Topics include algebraic, functional, and graphical techniques for solving problems with algebraic, exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric functions and their inverses. May only be used for degree credit with departmental approval.

courses.title: Support for Differential Calculus
courses.description: This corequisite studio course provides extra precalculus support for students enrolled in Math 1551, Differential Calculus.

courses.title: Calculus I
courses.description: Differential calculus and basic integral calculus including the fundamental theorem of calculus. Credit not allowed for both MATH 1501 and 1712.

courses.title: Calculus I for the Life Sciences
courses.description: Differential and basic calculus: sequences, difference equations, limits, continuity, differentiation, integration, applications.  The topics parallel those of MATH 1501 with applications from life sciences.

courses.title: Calculus I for the Life Sciences
courses.description: Taylor approximations, introduction to differential equations, linear algebra, and introduction to multivariable calculus.  Motivating examples drawn from life sciences.

courses.title: Honors Calculus II
courses.description: The topics covered parallel those of 1502 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment.  Credit not allowed for both honors calculus and the corresponding regular calculus course.  Credit not allowed for both MATH 1512 and MATH 1522.  Credit not allowed for both MATH 1512 and MATH 15X2.

courses.title: Introduction to Differential Calculus
courses.description: An introduction to differential calculus including applications and the underlying theory of limits for functions and sequences. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1550 and MATH 1501, MATH 1551, or MATH 1503.

courses.title: Differential Calculus
courses.description: Differential calculus including applications and the underlying theory of limits for functions and sequences. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1551 and MATH 1501, MATH 1503, or MATH 1550.

courses.title: Integral Calculus
courses.description: Integral calculus: Definite and indefinite integrals, techniques of integration, improper integrals, infinite series, applications. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1552 and MATH 1502, MATH 1504, MATH 1512 or MATH 1555.

courses.title: Introduction to Linear Algebra
courses.description: An introduction to linear alegbra including eigenvalues and eigenvectors, applications to linear systems, least squares. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1553 and MATH 1522, MATH 1502, MATH 1504, MATH 1512, MATH 1554 or MATH 1564.

courses.title: Linear Algebra
courses.description: Linear algebra eigenvalues, eigenvectors, applications to linear systems, least squares, diagnolization, quadratic forms.

courses.title: Calculus for Life Sciences
courses.description: Overview of intergral calculus, multivariable calculus, and differential equations for biological sciences. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1555 and MATH 1552, MATH 1502, MATH 1504, MATH 1512 or MATH 2550.

courses.title: Linear Algebra with Abstract Vector Spaces
courses.description: This is an intensive first course in linear algebra including the theories of linear transformations and abstract vector spaces. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1564 and MATH 1553, MATH 1554, MATH 1522, MATH 1502, MATH 1504 or MATH 1512.

courses.title: Introduction to Higher Mathematics
courses.description: This course is designed to teach problem solving and proof writing.  Mathematical subject matter is drawn from elementary number theory and geometry.

courses.title: Finite Mathematics
courses.description: Linear equations, matrices, linear programming, sets and counting, probability and statistics.

courses.title: Survey of Calculus
courses.description: Techniques of differentiation, integration, application of integration to probability and statistics, multidimensional calculus. Credit not allowed for both MATH 1712 and 1501.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in Mathematics.

courses.title: Foundations of Mathematical Proof
courses.description: An introduction to proofs in advanced mathematics, intended as a transition to upper division courses including Abstract Algebra I and Analysis I.

courses.title: Abstract Vector Spaces
courses.description: A proof-based development of linear algebra and vector spaces, with additional topics such as multilinear algebra and group theory.

courses.title: Introduction to Multivariable Calculus
courses.description: Vectors in three dimensions, curves in space, functions of several variables, partial derivatives, optimization, integration of functions of several variables. Vector Calculus not covered. Credit will not be awarded for both MATH 2550 and MATH 2605 or MATH 2401 or MATH 2551 or MATH 1555.

courses.title: Multivariable Calculus
courses.description: Multivariable calculus: Linear approximation and Taylor's theorems, Lagrange multiples and constrained optimization, multiple integration and vector analysis including the theorems of Green, Gauss, and Stokes. Credit will not be awarded for both MATH 2551 and MATH 2401 or MATH 2411 or MATH 2561.

courses.title: Differential Equations
courses.description: Methods for obtaining numerical and analytic solutions of elementary differential equations. Applications are also discussed with an emphasis on modeling. Credit not awarded for both MATH 2552 and MATH 2403 or MATH 2413 or MATH 2562.

courses.title: Honors Multivariable Calculus
courses.description: The topics covered parallel those of MATH 2551 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment. Credit not awarded for both MATH 2561 and MATH 2401 or MATH 2411 or MATH 2551.

courses.title: Honors Differential Equations
courses.description: The topics covered parallel those of MATH 2552 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment.

courses.title: Introduction to Discrete Mathematics
courses.description: Mathematical logic and proof, mathematical induction, counting methods, recurrence relations, algorithms and complexity, graph theory and graph algorithms. Credit not awarded for both MATH 2603 and MATH 2602.

courses.title: Calculus III for Computer Science
courses.description: Topics in linear algebra and multivariate calculus and their applications in optimization and numerical methods, including curve fitting, interpolation, and numerical differentiation and integration.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Foundations of Mathematics and Computing
courses.description: This course introduces the essential mathematical concepts and computational techniques that form the basis of modern computing.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Applied Combinatorics
courses.description: Elementary combinatorial techniques used in discrete problem solving: counting methods, solving linear recurrences, graph and network models, related algorithms, and combinatorial designs.

courses.title: Applied Combinatorics Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for MATH 3012.

courses.title: Honors Applied Combinatorics
courses.description: Topics are parallel to those of MATH 3012 with a more rigorous and intensive treatment. Credit is not allowed for both MATH 3012 and 3022.

courses.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics
courses.description: This course is a problem-oriented introduction to the basic concepts of probability and statistics, providing a foundation for applications and further study.

courses.title: Honors Probability and Statistics
courses.description: The topics covered parallel those of MATH 3215, with a more rigorous and intensive treatment.  Credit is not allowed for both MATH 3215 and 3225.

courses.title: Probability Theory
courses.description: This course is a mathematical introduction to probability theory, covering random variables, moments, multivariable distributions, law of large numbers, central limit theorem, and large deviations. Credit not awarded for both MATH 3235 and MATH 3215 or 3225 or 3670.

courses.title: Statistical Theory
courses.description: An introduction to theoretical statistics for students with a background in probability. A mathematical formalism for inference on experimental data will be developed. Credit not awared for both MATH 3236 and MATH 3215 or 3225 or 3670.

courses.title: A Second Course in Linear Algebra
courses.description: This course will cover important topics in linear algebra not usually discussed in a first-semester course, featuring a mixture of theory and applications.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics with Applications
courses.description: Introduction to probability, probability distributions, point estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, linear regression and analysis of variance. Students cannot receive credit for both MATH 3670 and MATH 3770 or ISYE 3770 or CEE 3770.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics for Computing and Machine Learning
courses.description: Introductory probability and statistics for computing and machine learning, from random variables, joint distribution and concentration inequalities to parameter estimation, statistical models and Bayesian simulation.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Algebraic Structures in Coding Theory
courses.description: Introduction to linear error correcting codes with an emphasis on the algebraic tools required, including matrices vector spaces, groups, polynomial rings, and finite fields.

courses.title: Introduction to Graph Theory
courses.description: The fundamentals of graph theory: trees, connectivity, Euler torus, Hamilton cycles, matchings, colorings, and Ramsey theory.

courses.title: Combinatorial Analysis
courses.description: Combinatorial problem-solving techniques including the use of generating functions, recurrence relations, Polya theory, combinatorial designs, Ramsey theory, matroids, and asymptotic analysis.

courses.title: Senior Project I
courses.description: The first of a two-course sequence of faculty-directed independent research culminating in the writing of a senior thesis and its presentation.

courses.title: Senior Project II
courses.description: The second course of a two-course sequence of faculty-directed independent research culminating in the writing of a senior thesis and its presentation.

courses.title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra I
courses.description: This course develops in the theme of "Arithmetic congruence and abstract algebraic structures". Strong emphasis on theory and proofs.

courses.title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra II
courses.description: Continuation of Abstract Algebra I, with emphasis on Galois theory, modules, polynomial fields, and the theory of linear associative algebra.

courses.title: Introduction to Number Theory
courses.description: Primes and unique factorization, congruences, Chinese remainder theorem, Diophantine equations, Diophantine approximations, quadratic reciprocity.  Applications such as fast multiplication, factorization, and encryption.

courses.title: Mathematical Foundations of Data Science
courses.description: Data science methods and their mathematical foundations: linear regression, classification, and clustering, kernel methods, regression trees and ensemble methods, dimension reduction.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes I
courses.description: Simple random walk and the theory of discrete time Markov chains.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes II
courses.description: Renewal theory, Poisson processes and continuous time Markov processes, including an introduction to Brownian motion and martingales.

courses.title: Monte Carlo Methods
courses.description: Probability distributions, limit laws, and applications through the computer.

courses.title: Mathematical Statistics I
courses.description: Sampling distributions, Normal, t, chi-square, and f distributions. Moment-generating function methods, Bayesian estimation, and introduction to hypothesis testing.

courses.title: Mathematical Statistics II
courses.description: Hypothesis testing, likelihood ratio tests, nonparametric tests, bivariate and multivariate normal distributions.

courses.title: Introduction to Information Theory
courses.description: The measurement and quantification of information.  These ideas are applied to the probabilistic analysis of the transmission of information over a channel along which random distortion of the message occurs.

courses.title: Topics in Linear Algebra
courses.description: Finite dimensional vector spaces, inner product spaces, least squares, linear transformations, the spectral theorem for normal transformations.  Applications to convex sets, positive matrices, difference equations.

courses.title: Analysis I
courses.description: Real numbers, topology of Euclidean spaces, Cauchy sequences, completeness, continuity and compactness, uniform continuity, series of functions, Fourier series.

courses.title: Analysis II
courses.description: Differentiation of functions of one real variable, Riemann-Stieltjes integral, the derivative in Rn, and integration in Rn.

courses.title: Complex Analysis
courses.description: Topics from complex function theory, including contour integration and conformal mapping.

courses.title: Partial Differential Equations I
courses.description: Method of characteristics for first- and second-order partial differential equations, conservation laws and shocks, classification of second-order systems and applications.

courses.title: Partial Differential Equations II
courses.description: Green's functions and fundamental solutions.  Potential, diffusion, and wave equations.

courses.title: Introductory Topology
courses.description: Point set topology, topological spaces and metric spaces, continuity and compactness, homotopy, and covering spaces.

courses.title: Introduction to Algebraic Topology
courses.description: Introduction to algebraic methods in topology. Includes homotopy, the fundamental group, covering spaces, simplicial complexes.  Applications to fixed point theory and group theory.

courses.title: Differential Geometry
courses.description: The theory of curves, surfaces, and more generally, manifolds.  Curvature, parallel transport, covariant differentiation, Gauss-Bonet theorem.

courses.title: Dynamics and Bifurcations I
courses.description: A broad introduction to the local and global behavior of nonlinear dynamical systems arising from maps and ordinary differential equations.

courses.title: Dynamics and Bifurcations II
courses.description: A continuation of Dynamics and Bifurcations I.

courses.title: Linear Programming
courses.description: A study of linear programming problems, including the simplex method, duality, and sensitivity analysis with applications to matrix games, interger programming, and networks.

courses.title: Classical Mathematical Methods in Engineering
courses.description: The Laplace transform and applications, Fourier series, boundary value problems for partial differential equations.

courses.title: Numerical Analysis I
courses.description: Introduction to numerical algorithms for some basic problems in computational mathematics.  Discussion of both implementation issues and error analysis.

courses.title: Numerical Analysis II
courses.description: Introduction to the numerical solution of initial and boundary value problems in differential equations.

courses.title: Undergraduate Internship
courses.description: Undergraduate internship for academic credit.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Computational Methods for Simulation and Machine Learning
courses.description: Introduction to numerical methods which are fundamental in modeling, simulation, and machine learning.

courses.title: Mathematical Biology
courses.description: Problems from the life sciences and the mathematical methods for solving them are presented.  The underlying biological and mathematical principles and the interrelationships are emphasized. Crosslisted with BIOL 4755.

courses.title: Vector and Parallel Scientific Computation
courses.description: Scientific computational algorithms on vector and parallel computers. Speed-up and algorithm complexity, interprocesses communication, synchronization, modern algorithms for linear systems, programming techniques, code optimization. Crosslisted with CS 4777.

courses.title: Quantum Information and Quantum Computing
courses.description: Introduction to quantum computing and quantum information theory, formalism of quantum mechanics, quantum gates, algorithms, measurements, coding, and information. Physical realizations and experiments. Crosslisted with PHYS 4782.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: This course enables the school of Mathematics to comply with requests for courses in selected topics.

courses.title: Reading or Research
courses.description: Reading or research in topics of current interest.

courses.title: Introduction to Graduate Studies in Mathematics
courses.description: This course covers practical information helping students start their careers as a professional mathematician. It also satisfies the Georgia Tech RCR requirements for "in-person" training.

courses.title: Graph Theory and Combinatorial Structures
courses.description: Fundamentals, connectivity, matchings, colorings, extremal problems, Ramsey theory, planar graphs, perfect graphs. Applications to operations research and the design of efficient algorithms.

courses.title: Topology of Euclidean Spaces
courses.description: Metric spaces, normed linear spaces, convexity, and separation; polyhedra and simplicial complexes; surfaces; Brouwer fixed point theorem.

courses.title: Advanced Linear Algebra
courses.description: An advanced course in Linear Algebra and applications.

courses.title: Modern Abstract Algebra I
courses.description: Graduate-level linear and abstract algebra including groups, finite fields, classical matrix groups and bilinear forms, multilinear algebra, and matroids. First of two courses.

courses.title: Modern Abstract Algebra II
courses.description: Graduate-level linear and abstract algebra including rings, fields, modules, some algebraic number theory and Galois theory. Second of two courses.

courses.title: Probability Theory for Scientists and Engineers
courses.description: Classical introduction to probability theory including expectation, notions of convergence, laws of large numbers, independence, large deviations, conditional expectation, martingales, and Markov chains.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes in Finance II
courses.description: Advanced mathematical modeling of financial markets, derivative securities pricing, and portfolio optimization. Concepts from advanced probability and mathematics are introduced as needed.

courses.title: Probability I
courses.description: Develops the probability basis requisite in modern statistical theories and stochastic processes.  Topics of this course include measure and integration foundations of probability, distribution functions, convergence concepts, laws of large numbers, and central limit theory. First of two courses.

courses.title: Probability II
courses.description: Develops the probability basis requisite in modern statistical theories and stochastic processes.  Topics of this course include results for sums of independent random variables, Markov processes, martingales, Poisson processes, Brownian motion, conditional probability and conditional expectation, and topics from ergodic theory.  Second of two classes.

courses.title: Advanced Statistical Inference I
courses.description: Basic theories of statistical estimation, including optimal estimation in finite samples and asymptotically optimal estimation.  A careful mathematical treatment of the primary techniques of estimation utilized by statisticians.

courses.title: Testing Statistical Hypotheses
courses.description: Basic theories of testing statistical hypotheses, including a thorough treatment of testing in exponential class families.  A careful mathematical treatment of the primary techniques of hypothesis testing utilized by statisticians.

courses.title: Linear Statistical Models
courses.description: Basic unifying theory underlying techniques of regression, analysis of variance and covariance, from a geometric point of view.  Modern computational capabilities are exploited fully.  Students apply the theory to real data through canned and coded programs.

courses.title: Multivariate Statistical Analysis
courses.description: Multivariate normal distribution theory, correlation and dependence analysis, regression and prediction, dimension-reduction methods, sampling distributions and related inference problems, selected applications in classification theory, multivariate process control, and pattern recognition.

courses.title: Ordinary Differential Equations I
courses.description: This sequence develops the qualitative theory for systems of ordinary differential equations. Topics include stability, Lyapunov functions, Floquet theory, attractors, invariant manifolds, bifurcation theory, normal forms. First of two courses.

courses.title: Ordinary Differential Equations II
courses.description: This sequence develops the qualitative theory for systems of differential equations. Topics include stability, Lyapunov functions, Floquet theory, attractors, invariant manifolds, bifurcation theory, and normal forms.  Second of two courses.

courses.title: Functions of a Complex Variable I
courses.description: Complex integration, including Goursat's theorem; classification of singularities, the argument principle, the maximum principle; Riemann Mapping theorem; analytic continuation and Riemann surfaces; range of an analytic function, including Picard's theorem.

courses.title: Real Analysis I
courses.description: Lebesgue measure and integration, differentiation, abstract measure theory. Credit cannot be received for both MATH 6337 and MATH 6579.

courses.title: Real Analysis II
courses.description:
Continuation of MATH 6337.  L^p and Hilbert spaces, introduction to operator theory and functional analysis.
Credit cannot be received for both MATH 6338 and MATH 6580.

courses.title: Partial Differential Equations I
courses.description: Introduction to the mathematical theory of partial differential equations covering the basic linear models of science and exact solution techniques.

courses.title: Partial Differential Equations II
courses.description: This course covers the general mathematical theory of linear stationary and evolution problems plus selected topics chosen from the instructor's interests.

courses.title: Algebraic Geometry I
courses.description: The study of zero sets of polynomials: algebraic varieties, regular and rational mappings, the Zariski topology.

courses.title: Algebraic Geometry II
courses.description: A continuation of Algebraic Geometry I.

courses.title: Algebraic Topology I
courses.description: Simplicial homology.  Chain complexes and acyclic carriers. Simplicial approximation.  The exact homology sequence. Maps of spheres. Mayer-Vietoris sequence.

courses.title: Algebraic Topology II
courses.description: Continuation of MATH 6441. Singular homology.  Local homology and manifolds. CW complexes.  Cohomology. Duality in manifolds.

courses.title: General Topology
courses.description: Introduction to topological and metric spaces. Continuity, compactness, convergence, completion.  Product and quotient spaces.  Elementary homotopy.

courses.title: Differential Topology
courses.description: Manifolds. Differentiable structures.  Tangent bundles. Embeddings and immersions.  Maps on manifolds. Transversality.  Morse-Sard Theorem. Vector bundles.

courses.title: Geometric Topology
courses.description: Characteristic classes, Morse theory, three-manifolds, four-manifolds, symplectic and contact manifolds, knot theory.

courses.title: Differential Geometry I
courses.description: Core topics in differential, including: Lie groups, curvature, and relations with topology.

courses.title: Differential Geometry II
courses.description: Introduces students to topics of current interest in geometry.

courses.title: Industrial Mathematics I
courses.description: Applied mathematics techniques to solve real-world problems. Topics include mathematical modeling, asymptotic analysis, differential equations and scientific computation.  Prepares the student for MATH 6515.

courses.title: Measure Theory for Scientists and Engineers
courses.description:
An introduction to measure theory and Lebesgue integration with a focus on topics that tend to be of the most utility in
science and engineering. Credit cannot be received for both MATH 6337 and MATH 6579.

courses.title: Hilbert Spaces for Scientists and Engineers
courses.description:
Structure of linear operators in infinite dimensional spaces, applications.
  Credit cannot be received for both MATH 6338 and MATH 6580.

courses.title: Integral Equations and Transforms
courses.description: Volterra and Fredholm linear integral equations; relation to differential equations; solution methods; Fourier, Laplace, and Mellin transforms; applications to boundary value problems and integral equations.

courses.title: Special Functions of Higher Mathematics
courses.description: Gamma function; exponential function; orthogonal polynomials; Bessel, Legendre, and hypergeometric functions; application to singular ordinary differential equations; and separation of variables for partial differential equations.

courses.title: Numerical Methods in Finance
courses.description: Basic numerical and simulation techniques used in the pricing of derivative securities and in related problems in finance. Some programming experience required.

courses.title: Introduction to Numerical Methods for Partial Differential Equations
courses.description: Introduction to the implementation and analysis of numerical algorithms for the numerical solution of the classic partial differential equations of science and engineering. Must have knowledge of a computer programming language, familiarity with partial differential equations and elements of scientific computing.

courses.title: Advanced Numerical Methods for Partial Differential Equations
courses.description: Analysis and implementation of numerical methods for nonlinear partial differential equations including elliptic, hyperbolic, and/or parabolic problems. Must have knowledge of classic linear partial differential equations and exposure to numerical methods for partial differential equations at the level of MATH 6640 or numerical linear algebra at the level of MATH 6643.

courses.title: Numerical Linear Algebra
courses.description: Introduction to the numerical solution of the classic problems of linear algebra including linear systems, least squares, Singular value decomposition, eigenvalue problems. Crosslisted with CSE 6643.

courses.title: Iterative Methods for Systems of Equations
courses.description: Iterative methods for linear and nonlinear systems of equations including Jacobi, G-S, SOR, CG, multigrid, Newton quasi-Newton, updating, and gradient-based methods. Crosslisted with CSE 6644.

courses.title: Numerical Approximation Theory
courses.description: Theoretical and computational aspects of polynomial, rational, trigonometric, spline, and wavelet approximation.

courses.title: Numerical Methods for Ordinary Differential Equations
courses.description: Analysis and implementation of numerical methods for initial and two-point boundary value problems for ordinary differential equations.

courses.title: Numerical Methods for Dynamical Systems
courses.description: Approximation of the dynamical structure of a differential equation and preservation of dynamical structure under discretization. Must be familiar with dynamical systems and numerical methods for initial and boundary value problems in ordinary differential equations.

courses.title: Math Methods of Applied Sciences I
courses.description: Review of linear algebra and ordinary differential equations, brief introduction to functions of a complex variable.

courses.title: Math Methods of Applied Sciences II
courses.description: Review of vector calculus and its applications to partial differential equations.

courses.title: Modeling and Dynamics
courses.description: Mathematical methods for solving problems in the life sciences.  Models-based course on basic facts from the theory of ordinary differential equations and numerical methods of their solution.  Introduction to the control theory, diffusion theory, maximization, minimization and curve fitting.  Math majors may not use this course toward any degree in the School of Mathematics.

courses.title: Numerical Methods in Computational Science and Engineering I
courses.description: Introduction to numerical algorithms widely used in computational science and engineering. Numerical linear algebra, linear programming, and applications. Crosslisted with CSE 6710.

courses.title: Numerical Methods in Computational Science and Engineering II
courses.description: Efficient numerical techniques for solving partial differential equations and large-scale systems of equations arising from discretization of partial differential equations or variational problems in applications in science and engineering. Crosslisted with CSE 6711.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes in Finance I
courses.description: Mathematical modeling of financial markets, derivative securities pricing, and portfolio optimization.  Concepts from probability and mathematics are introduced as needed. Crosslisted with ISYE 6759.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes I
courses.description: Discrete time Markov chains, Poisson processes, and renewal processes. Transient and limiting behavior.  Average cost and utility measures of systems.  Algorithms for computing performance measures.  Modeling of inventories, and flows in manufacturing and computer networks. Crosslisted with ISYE 6761.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes II
courses.description: Continuous time Markov chains. Uniformization, transient and limiting behavior.  Brownian motion and martingales. Optional sampling and convergence.  Modeling of inventories, finance, flows in manufacturing and computer networks. Crosslisted with ISYE 6762.

courses.title: Design and Implementation of Systems to Support
courses.description: Computational Finance Introduction to large scale system design to support computational finance for options, stocks, or other financial instruments. Some programming experience, and previous exposure to stocks, bonds, and options required. Crosslisted with ISYE 6767.

courses.title: Fixed Income Securities
courses.description: Description, institutional features, and mathematical modeling of fixed income securities.  Use of both deterministic and stochastic models. Crosslisted with ISYE 6769.

courses.title: Statistical Techniques of Financial Data Analysis
courses.description: Fundamentals of statistical inference for models used in the modern analysis of financial data. Crosslisted with ISYE 6783.

courses.title: The Practice of Quantitative and Computational Finance
courses.description: Case studies, visiting lecturers from financial institutions, student group projects of an advanced nature, and student reports, all centered around quantitative and computational finance. Crosslisted with ISYE and MGT 6785.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Quantitative and Computational Finance
courses.description: Advanced foundational material and analysis techniques in quantitative and computational finance. Crosslisted with ISYE 6793.

courses.title: Enumerative Combinatorics
courses.description: Fundamental methods of enumeration and asymptotic analysis, including the use of inclusion/exclusion, generating functions, and recurrence relations.  Applications to strings over a finite alphabet and graphs.

courses.title: Advanced Graph Theory
courses.description: Advanced topics in graph theory.  Selection of arguments varies every year.

courses.title: Combinatorics
courses.description: Fundamental combinatorial structures including hypergraphs, transversal sets, colorings, Sperner families, intersecting families, packings and coverings, perfect graphs, and Ramsey theory.  Algebraic and topological methods, applications.

courses.title: Probabilistic Methods in Combinatorics
courses.description: Applications of probabilistic techniques in discrete mathematics, including classical ideas using expectation and variance as well as modern tools, such as martingale and correlation inequalities.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes and Stochastic Calculus I
courses.description: An introduction to the Ito stochastic calculus and stochastic differential equations through a development of continuous-time martingales and Markov processes. First of two courses.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes and Stochastic Calculus II
courses.description: An introduction to the Ito stochastic calculus and stochastic differential equations through a development of continuous-time martingales and Markov processes. Continuation of MATH 7244.

courses.title: High-dimensional probability
courses.description: The goal of this PhD level graduate course is to provide a rigorous introduction to the methods of high-dimensional probability.

courses.title: High-dimensional statistics
courses.description: The goal of this PhD level graduate course is to provide a rigorous introduction to the methods of high-dimensional statistics.

courses.title: Harmonic Analysis
courses.description: Fourier analysis on the torus and Euclidean space.

courses.title: Functional Analysis
courses.description: Spectral theory of bounded and unbounded operators, major theorems of functional analysis, additional topics.

courses.title: Advanced Analysis
courses.description:
A comprehensive overview of advanced material in analysis. This is a Repeatable Course with 5 different subtitles;
Recommended prerequisites may vary with each offering.

courses.title: Graph Algorithms
courses.description: Algorithms for graph problems such as maximum flow, covering, matching, coloring, planarity, minimum cuts, shortest paths, and connectivity.  Crosslisted with ISYE 7510 and CS 7510.

courses.title: Calculus of Variations
courses.description: Minimization of functionals, Euler-Lagrange equations, sufficient conditions for a minimum; geodesic, isoperometric, and time of transit problems; variational principles of mechanics; applications to control theory.

courses.title: Tensor Analysis
courses.description: Review of linear algebra, multilinear algebra, algebra of tensors, co- and contravariant tensors, tensors in Riemann spaces, geometrical interpretation of skew tensors.

courses.title: Aural-Oral English Skills for Math ESL International Teaching Assistants
courses.description: Enhancement of English listening/speaking skills for SOM international graduate students, post-docs, and new faculty who speak English as their second language (ESL) and who will be teaching undergraduate students.

courses.title: Academic Communication for Intermediate ESL Math International Teaching Assistants
courses.description: Continued enhancement of English listening/speaking skills for current and future SOM graduate international teaching assistants and international lead instructors who speak English as their second language (ESL).

courses.title: Academic Communication for Advanced ESL Math International Teaching Assistants
courses.description: Continued enhancement of English listening/speaking skills for current and future SOM graduate international teaching assistants and international lead instructors who speak English as their second language (ESL).

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: This course enables the School of Mathematics to comply with requests for courses in selected topics.
